1105461943484198913.text:
Very happy to share a new blog post about how to compute an exponential function inside a SNARK for Coda's proof-of-stake.

It has some fun and useful math about approximating the continuous with the discrete. 

https://codaprotocol.com/blog/taylor.html …pic.twitter.com/Iy5mXJ3YeB

1105155672860049408.text:
I like this example because it reminds you that categories aren’t just these big scary mathematical universes like Set or Top, but also little algebraic objects like monoids or groups that can help us describe discrete situations. 

6/6

1105155624327884800.text:
Which category? It has as its objects natural numbers 0, 1, … and the maps i -> j are the strings of length |j - i|. Composition is just concatenation. 

5/

1105155531369439236.text:
This means if two strings overlap in a significant chunk, you can share the computation done on that chunk. This is essential for writing an efficient snark. 

An easy way to say this is that H is a functor from a certain category C to the group G (considered as a category).

4/

1105155366134833158.text:
Let's define a new version of H which takes an offset k, with H_k(b1 … bm) = b1 g_{1+k} + … + bm * g_{m+k}.

The efficiency property is this: if s1 is a string of length k and s2 is a string, then H(s1 ++ s2) = H(s1) + H_k(s2) where ++ is string concatenation.

3/

1105155041516675075.text:
The hash function H takes bitstrings as input and returns an element of some group G. The best version operates on triples of bits, but its a bit complicated to described. Random elements g1, …, gn : G are fixed and H is defined by H(b1 … bn) = b1 * g1 + … + bn * gn.

2/

1105154602268188673.text:
The Pedersen hash function (esp.  that of @feministPLT and @ebfull) is a great example of applied category theory. It's a super SNARK-efficient hash function that comes with a nice efficiency property that is easily expressed in the language of category theory. 
1/

here’s an example http://drops.dagstuhl.de/opus/volltexte/2016/5855/pdf/34.pdf … where they notice some proofs of A => B are actually constructive proofs of not A => not B, which yields a fruitful algorithm.

Not sure if they had the constructivist philosophy directly in mind, but it sort of permeates TCS
